label: q_it05_q07_temporal
content:
{
  "question_id": "it05_q07_temporal",
  "scope_id": "insider_threat_05",
  "checkpoint_after": 25,
  "question_type": "temporal",
  "prompt": "When did the anomalous access pattern first appear, and over how many weeks did the data transfer volume escalate?",
  "ground_truth": {
    "canonical_answer": "The anomalous access pattern first appeared during the early signal phase when jmorris began accessing repositories outside their current assignment. Data transfer volume escalated over approximately 3-4 weeks from 200MB/day baseline to over 1GB/day.",
    "required_evidence_refs": [
      "insider_threat_05_ep_010",
      "insider_threat_05_ep_011",
      "insider_threat_05_ep_016",
      "insider_threat_05_ep_019"
    ],
    "key_facts": [
      "lateral information gathering pattern inconsistent with declared operational role",
      "data transfer volumes from a single account diverge from peer group norms in a sustained multi-week pattern",
      "data transfer volumes escalated progressively over a multi-week period with each successive week showing higher peak transfer sizes than the previous",
      "the anomalous data access pattern originates from a single authorized internal account, not from external network intrusion",
      "the data exfiltration uses authorized access paths rather than exploiting software vulnerabilities",
      "red team exercise alerts are not related to the exfiltration activity"
    ]
  }
}
